title: 113_s2417
content: The "Close the Revolving Door Act of 2014" includes a lifetime ban on members of Congress from lobbying. The "Close the Revolving Door Act of 2014" imposes restrictions on former members of Congress lobbying. Amendments to title 18, United States Code, include prohibiting former Senators, Members of the House of Representatives, or elected officers from influencing current members or employees of Congress on behalf of others. SEC. 3. CONGRESSIONAL STAFF amended to increase term limit to 6 years. SEC. 4. Improved reporting of lobbyists' activities through a joint web database. SEC. 5. Lobbyist revolving door restrictions for former members of Congress. Any person who is a registered lobbyist or agent of a foreign principal cannot be hired by a Member or committee of Congress they had substantial lobbying contact with for 6 years. A waiver can be granted by the Committee on Ethics or Standards of Official Conduct for a compelling national need. Lobbying contacts must be related to legislative business, earmarks, or fundraising to be considered substantial. Lobbying contacts with Members or committee of Congress must be related to legislative business, earmarks, or fundraising to be considered substantial. Simple social contacts do not count as substantial lobbying contacts. SEC. 6A. REPORTING BY SUBSTANTIAL LOBBYING ENTITIES. The Lobbying Disclosure Act of 1995 is amended to include reporting requirements for substantial lobbying entities. Substantial lobbying entities must annually file a list of former lawmakers or congressional staff members they employ, along with job descriptions, with the Clerk of the House of Representatives and the Secretary of the United States Senate. The Joint Web site lobbyists.gov will have a database for 'Substantial Lobbying Entities' with employee job descriptions. The Clerk of the House and the Secretary of the Senate will share filings with the DC US Attorney for oversight. The term 'Substantial Lobbying Entity' is defined in this section. The term 'substantial lobbying entity' is defined as an incorporated entity that employs more than 3 federally registered lobbyists during a filing period. SEC. 7 of the Lobbying Disclosure Act of 1995 is amended to increase penalties from $200,000 to $500,000.
